abstract: moval studies. I. Dispersal strategies of sympatric Sigmodon hispidWi and Reithrodontomys fulvescens populations,

abstract.text: moval studies. I. Dispersal strategies of sympatric Sigmodon hispidWi and Reithrodontomys fulvescens populations,

body_text.text: Continuing field work in Paraguay by representatives from the University of Michigan, University of Connecticut, Peace Corps, and Servicio Forestal Nacional of the Paraguayan Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, and examination of previously collected specimens, have revealed the presence of an additional five species of bats in that country. With recent reports by Wetzel and Lovett (1974), Wetl.el et al. (1975) , Myers (1977) , Harrison et aL (1979) , Myers and Wetzel (1979) , Wetzel (1980 ), Baud (1981 , and Myers and Carleton (1981) , this brings to 24 the number of mammal species added to the Paraguayan fauna in the last decade
body_text.section: ADDITIONAL RECORDS OF BATS FROM PARAGUAY

body_text.text: The specimens reported here are deposited in the University of Michigan Museum of Zoology (U~1MZ), University of Connecticut Museum of Natural History (CONN), American Museum of Natural History (AMNH), Field Museum of Natural History (FMNH), British Museum of Natural History (BMNH), and the collection of the Servicio Fo,!:'stal \1acional of Paraguay (SF'""). Capitalizpd color terms are from Hidg\\ ay
body_text.section: ADDITIONAL RECORDS OF BATS FROM PARAGUAY
ADDITIONAL RECORDS OF BATS FROM PARAGUAY

body_text.text: Halo (6 SFN, 2 UMMZ). All specimens were taken in nets set across the entrance to caves and crevices in limestone cliffs, The roosts were shared with Glossopiwga $oricina and Desmodus rotundus. Paraguayan specimens of Peropteryx closely resemble a series of P. macrotis from Corumba (Malo Grosso, Brazil) housed in the FMNH Tonalia biden5 (Spix),-Boqueron: Orloff (l F\INH). 1tap!ia: 2 km I\~W San Rafael, :\rroyo San Hafael (l UMMZ). Nueva Asunci6n; km 589, Trans Chaco Highway, COPAGRQ (1 UMMZ). Paraguari; Sapucay (1 BMNH; G 0. Handley, Jr., pefs. comm.) . The specimen from Dept. Nueva Asuncion was captured over an isolated pond in thorn scrub with specimens of Myotis nigricans, Molossops temmincki, Eumops bonariensis, Promops nasutus, and Molossus molossus. The specimen from Dept. Itapua entered a net set over a stream flowing through high tropical forest. Other species captured at or within a few kilometers of that locality include Artibeus lituratus, Artibeus sp., Pygoderma hilahiaturn, Sturn/ra lilium, Eptesicus brasiliensis, E. diminu/us, E. fUrinalis, LasiuTUS borealis, L. ega, Myotis riparius, M. TUber, and Molossops abrasus. Details concerning the capture of the third specimen (Dept. Boqueron) are not available; the general appearance of the area around Orloff, however, resembles the capture site of the specimen from Dept. Nueva Asuncion. These animals, and two specimens in the FMNH from Mato Grosso, Brazil (Urucum de Corumba), are slightly larger than Central American T. bidens, based on comparison with four specimens from Guatemala in the FMNH (mean of selected measurements of males, n = 4, from Brazi! and Paraguay, followed by mean for males, n = 2, from Guatemala: greatest length of skull 27.4, 27.2; condylobasallength 24.1,23.8; zygomatic breadth 13.3, 12.8; interorbital breadth 5.8, 5.5; distance across canines 6.0, 5.5).
body_text.section: ADDITIONAL RECORDS OF BATS FROM PARAGUAY

body_text.text: Vampyressa pusilla pusilla (\Vagner).-Paraguar[: Parque :\'acional YhFU! (3 Ui\li\lZ, 3 SF:\). Th!'"se bats entered mist nets set at the edge of a smalt clearing in subtropical forest. Other bats captured at the same locality are Artibeus lilumtus, Artibeus sp., Vampyrops lineatus, Sturn/ra liIium, Caroilia perspicillata, Desmodus rotundus, Eplesicus fUrinaliS, Lasiurus borealis, Myotis nigricans, M. riparius, Molossops abrasus, M. temmincki. The only female captured (June) was pregnant
body_text.section: ADDITIONAL RECORDS OF BATS FROM PARAGUAY

body_text.text: The type specimen of V. pusiI/a is a mounted skin containing the skull (type locality, Sapitiva, southeastern Brazil). Goodwin (1963) provided photographs and measurements of the holotype, and noted that its phalangeal epiphyses were unfused. He further described a new species, V. nattereri, also from southeastern Brazil, and differing from V. pusilla primarily in characters attributable to age, which prompted Handley (1966) and Peterson (1968) to place V. nattereri in synonymy under v. pusilla pusilla. The Paraguayan specimens agree qualitatively with nattereri and pusilla as described by Goodwin (1963) and Peterson (1968) . They are slightly larger than the (immature) holotype of pusilla and slightly smaller than the holotype of nattereri [selected measurements from the holotype of nalfereri, from Goodwin, 1963, foHowed by means from the males from Paraguay (n = 2): forearm 35.0, 32.4; greatest length of skuH 20.1, 19.6; condylobasallength IB.3, 17.7; zygomatic breadth 12.1, 11.7; interorbital breadth 5.2, 5.0; mastoidal breadth 10.1, 9.8; width across Mi!_M2 8.6, 8.4; maxillary toothrow length 6.7, 6.4]. Measurements of additional specimens of pusilla from southeastern Brazil were reported by Taddei (1979) and agree with Goodwin's measurements for the type of nattereri. Vampyressa pusilla from Paraguay are larger than V. p. thyone from Central America, though similar in qualitative characteristics concerning tooth shape and number, form of the soft tissues of the palate, and shape of the rhinarial opening. The karyotype of the three Paraguayan specimens (2n = 20 and FN = 36) is unlike any of the chromosomal morphs reported for northern populations of this species (summarized by Gardner, 1977) Eptesicus brasiliensis argentinus Thomas.-ltapua: 20 km (by rd.) !\!\E Encarnaci6n (l C\1\lZ); 8 km N San Rafael (3 UMMZ). These specimens were netted over a sma!! artificial pond and a stream, both surrounded by tropical forest. Two females were captured in July; neither showed signs of reproductive activity. Other bat species captured at the same localities are listed under T. bidens. Thomas (1920) described E. argentinus and distinguished it from E. brasiliensis by its larger size and lightpr color. Davis (1966) confirmcd this distinction, but, following Cahrera (1958), l:onsidpred argenlinus a subspecies of brasiliensis. Measurements of the Paraguayan specimens are large and, compared to measurements of E. h. brasiliensis and E. h. argentinus reported by Davis (1966) , are similar to E. h. argentinus. They lack the pale tint of argentinus, however, and dorsally range in color from Mahogany Red to approximate!} Mummy Brown, and ventral!y from Antique Brown to Prout's Brown t:ptcsicus diminutus fidelis Thomas.-Itapua: 8 km ~ San Rafael (2 CMl\lZ), If'ft bank of Rio Pirapo, I km l\ Rio Parana (l CONN). These bats entered a net set over a small stream in tropical forest. Three females, captured in July, were neither pregnant nor lactating.
body_text.section: ADDITIONAL RECORDS OF BATS FROM PARAGUAY

body_text.text: Previous reports of Eptesieus dorianus or Eptesicus fidelis (=E. diminutus) in Paraguay (Davis, 1966; Wetzel and Lovett, 1974) were based on misidentified E. furinalis (Williams, 1978) . Three species of Eptesicils coexist in rainforest along the Rio Parana and were captured together in the same net. Eplesieus
body_text.section: ADDITIONAL RECORDS OF BATS FROM PARAGUAY
